cons: Long lines. During peak hours, expect a large audience to stare at you while you are making their drinks. Picky, rude customers who try complicated "hacks" to get the same drink for cheaper. Unreliable and confusing tablet system to ring up. Casual misandry and unnecessary yelling from coworkers and management. Training is nonexistent, basically shadowing someone who may be too busy to explain what's going on. After that, it's sink or swim. Easily the worst job I've ever experienced - destroys your mental health.

job_title: Sr. Administrative Specialist in Denton, TX
pros: -Good healthcare -Relaxed dress code (department dependent)
cons: -Insane workload during peak times -Poor institutional memory. Meaning that every time someone leaves no one has any idea how to do the things they did because UNT doesn't believe in redundancy and will hire as few people as possible. -Incompetent leadership (How they're able to choose this many bad leaders I'm not sure) -Training what training? Believe it or not, a generic PowerPoint is not a replacement for being able to ask a real-life person questions! -Extremely poor pay. I don't think I need to expand on this point. The pay is generally insulting for the amount of work and passion that they expect. -Working in an academic department with faculty where there are no other staff members or limited staff means that the majority of your time will be spent with people who actively talk down to you, think they're your boss (even if they aren't), and who 9/10 treat with you a lack of respect. In short faculty & staff relations at UNT are very poor and UNT shows that it doesn't care for its staff routinely.

job_title: Computer Operator I in Denton, TX
pros:
Flexible schedule; my manager worked with me while I was enrolled in classes. Great medical benefits and tuition discount. I'm blessed to have great co-workers and many amazing students I was able to collaborate with on projects.

Great situation for a student, as a transitional job, or an individual ready to focus on retirement benefits.
cons:
Performance reviews are a formality to meet compliance. They hold no weight in terms of any compensation adjustment despite major responsibility increases.

Leadership became detached and unempathetic in regards to how the pandemic affected the rest of the IT system workforce. 

No response or discussions on the plan of action when multiple employees including students tested positive for Covid-19. I found this out on return from my quarantine period post-negative test result. I recommended our department maintain our prior hybrid work schedule to reduce contact and meet better social distancing requirements a few months before this incident. Our department was required to remain remote and the rest of the workforce was allowed to work remotely. 

Leadership is willing to sacrifice employee safety and minimize employee concerns.

A questionable selection process for open internal positions. (I believe an ideal candidate should be measured on value, skill development, and interest in the role performed during the interview process and not pre-selected by the department manager with reasons being a "close friend on hard times.")

review_title: Best job, best bosses, best coworkers, worst pay.
pros: I worked as videographer for UNT’s Dining Marketing department, and it was amazing. My bosses were fantastic, the office was super clean and modern, we had two daily huddles at assigned times during the day (which we’re both productive AND typically hilarious), and I got free food like you wouldn’t believe. I got a meal ticket for every four hour shift I worked that I could use for pizza or Chick Fil A or whatever I wanted. And there was always some cool new test food, brought over by the chefs, free to grab in the break room. It was an honor to get to work with such talented and friendly coworkers.
cons: The PAY!! Student pay at UNT is $8.25/hr. It doesn’t matter what job you do— whether you’re flipping fries in a dining hall or animating motion graphics and editing a twenty minute training video, it’s all the same in the eyes of the university.

pros:
-free room and board
-monthly stipend of around $300
cons:
- exploitative workplace
- expectation that student staff prioritize job over school, then punished staff for poor grades
- traumatizing work environment: high stress situations without resources for staff. No additional compensation for traumatizing events. 
- Admin does not listen to student staff unless student staff are “agreeable”. (I.e. Christian, straight, male, and “clean cut”)
- Admin encourages employees to ignore their duty of mandatory reporting to keep the academy’s name clean.
- Employees work directly with teenagers in a competitive boarding school setting but are not given the means to help students. Mental health is a huge part of the job, their current resources are insufficient and do not accommodate the amount of students that need help. This job falls on to the resident assistants and program advisors. Management expects staff to not be too involved and those who are overly involved in attempting to help students find other resources will be punished. Staff is also punished when they are unable to help their students enough. It’s a toxic cycle.
- Meetings (one on ones) with management often become incredibly abusive and invasive. Management routinely crosses boundaries with staff and belittles them for “failure”. These meetings lack professionalism.
- induction ceremony (hazing)

pros: Room and board, monthly stipend, retail dining stipend, making connections with residents. You get to meet a lot of new people and experience a lot of things on and around campus. There's a lot of room for personal and professional growth and you get to attend a lot of diversity and inclusion trainings to grow as a human.
cons: Lots of work, you live where you work, encountering a lot of traumatic experiences, high expectations, time consuming.

Department of Equity and Diversity is underfunded, but they love bragging about their diversity (which is dubious at best). All of this is public information. Go look for yourself.
Several departments are not in accordance with affirmative action.
They use a hiring point system. What this translates to: You can already be performing the duties of a job, but won't be considered qualified by HR to do the actual job.* But they'll still expect you to do the same duties regardless, and it does impact your performance evaluation. Burnout and exhaustion are typical. 
Slashing budgets.
Nonsensical decision making from leadership.
Understaffed departments.

cons:
Upper management rarely ever came to our shop and never got to know any of us to any great extent. Bosses are all smiles but work behind your back and non inclusive. Talk the talk but sure don't walk the walk.

Management always wanted us to do more with less, hard to squeeze blood out of a turnip. 
Payroll... no pay advancement except for infrequent merit raises. The employee classification system is the pits with low pay whereas UPPER Management gets paid huge money to boss around staff and thus create poor morale for staff that have no upward mobility. Upper management is way overloaded and overpaid, ie; too many overpaid chiefs and not enough Indians to make things flow smoothly. 
I could go on, but I am sure you get the drift.

review_title: Great Benefits, No Opportunity for Growth
job_title: Administrative Coordinator III in Denton, TX
pros: As part of the State government, there is great stability unlike in the private sector. Benefits, including group insurance and pension plan, are top shelf, and vacation and sick time accruals are very generous.
cons: There is no opportunity for growth under the current staff organizational scheme. The career band model was only partially implemented, leading to stagnation, injured morale, and inability to grow in a position along with personal growth. There is no career progression without changing departments, making advancement nearly non-existent. Many faculty have no concept of what staff do for them, and are often demanding and expect staff to do things that could be accomplished by their teaching assistants if the faculty member had not waited until the last moment to complete a task. Faculty and administrators should stop sending emails to their support staff after a certain hour, or at least not expect them to be read and answered outside of normal 'office hours.'

review_title: As a faculty, you may have a satisfactory career. Or not.
pros: Nice neighborhood, appealing location, and wonderful student body. The IT infrastructure is surprisingly advanced for a school of this caliber. The proximity to Dallas is great and will get better once the major highway construction is completely by 2017.
cons: An organization with an aging culture, trying hard to enter the modern age, UNT still values its faculty far less than it should. Departmental politics can (and very, very frequently does) get vicious! The top administration is too busy, too removed, too helpless to do anything about it. There is much lip service paid to the value of teaching. Yet, outstanding teaching faculty typically earn a fraction of those who devote themselves to research at the cost of enhancing student outcomes. This kills morale faster than butter melts on a stove top!

review_title: Great place for experience and professional development in higher ed.
pros: UNT Housing Dept. has a lot of people who have been in higher ed for a long time and care deeply about students and student development. They consistently incorporate new projects, committees, and projects that challenge and cater to different skill sets. Director is incredibly available, approachable, and a leader I would follow into battle. She is wonderful and so helpful in professionally developing people along their career journey.
cons: A lot of people in the Housing department are UNT born and raised, which can make things feel very "we do things this way because we've always done them this way" and can be a hard environment for new-comers to feel welcome. Most of the employees try to work against this, but inside jokes during meetings are somewhat inevitable. Another con is there are people who are, or have been, on staff for a lot longer than they should be, based on inappropriate staff relationships or lack of drive/being completely checked out. Can be draining to work alongside people of either category, and was always frustrating to me.

review_title: Wonderful working for a large university.
job_title: Student Contact Representative in Denton, TX
pros: The biggest pro to working for UNT is the insurance benefits and paid time off.  Generally whenever class is not in session most office are closed, this is in addition to your paid vacation and sick leave.  Most of the amenities that are available to the students are available to employees, some with a modest fee but nothing compared to what you would pay off campus.
cons: The biggest con about working at UNT was the fact that it is extremely difficult to be promoted upwardly rather than laterally.  I was there from July 2007 to January 2011 and ended with the same position and salary I started with.  I applied for over 45 jobs throughout the campus and received only a handful of interviews and no other offers.  This is the same for just about all of my coworkers.   My position could not even be expanded so that I could be offered a larger salary, you get what you start with. The only reason I no longer work at UNT was because I had no future there.  It is deplorable in my opinion to work four years in one job with no promotion nor salary increase.

review_title: This is specifically for UNT System
pros: You are a state employee and receive a lot of time off; 12 days a year vacation and 12 days a year sick, accrued at 1 of each per month.  Also, they offer flex schedules. Although, they are not that flexible it does allow an option to work slightly different hours; 7-4 or 8-4:30 with a 30 minute lunch for example.
cons: Often times you have to work overtime, but earn comp time as opposed to overtime wages.  To use the comp time you have to submit a leave request.  Although you earn a lot of vacation time, there are not a lot of opportunities to take it.  Unless you are upper management, you word in a cubicle and have zero privacy.  It is very rigid and rule/policy oriented.  Also, because you are a state employee, you are required to put 7.2 % of your earnings into your retirement fund.

pros: Great place to further education
cons: Can be very pricey depending

review_title: If you can take the negativity from management, it's an okay place to work.
pros: The benefits are pretty good despite the economy and the pay could be better for most people here but some departments pay pretty well, such as anything having to do with Infomation Technology and I hear the Police Department got a heck of a raise when the rest of us didn't get anything.  They are pretty flexible if you want time off and they have the department covered and you have the time.  They don't demand your life but do expect you to put in the time.  There are so many different departments too.
cons: If you aren't a departmental favorite, forget getting anywhere other than the bottom!  Plus, they micro-manage you big time!  There is very little trust much of anywhere on campus amongst employees!  Be careful who you say what to...it'll come back to bite you!  Just do your job, don't make any friends here and go home...you'll be better for it.

review_title: A fun environment with some good and bad people.
pros: Good pay for a part time student position, flexible hours, you work with many other students which can be pretty fun, and the pay is relatively good.
cons: Some management was very shady in ways they handled things. The department I worked in received a pay cut in order to save some money for a new building as well as every other department minus one who received a pay raise. This department did not deserve a raise, received no new responsibilities, and did practically nothing aside from having a pretty face. Overall many departments were upset because the top tier management made all decisions without even consulting our managers or asking for advice on how to do things. Eventually they asked for their advice after enough people from multiple departments complained and things were rearranged to satisfaction. My position specifically went from $15/hr to $9/hr at first. We later got it raised to $11/hr do to logical complaints.

pros: Great people! I got to work with a lot of the faculty and rub shoulders with the people in the Dean's office and advising office. Lots of perks like getting paid to go represent the school at public events, lots of networking.  Good introductory job if you could use some cash, but not trying to rely on the income. There is a small scholarship every semester to try to smooth things out, but it's only like $500 and it's only in the fall and spring even though you're expected to work summers (even if you're taking classes in the summer).  You get to do lots of tours and meet new people all the time.
cons: The hours were kind of sporadic. If you're looking for a steady job with lots of hours, this isn't for you. I worked maybe 2-3 tours a week (tours are 1-2hrs each @ $10 an hour), with maybe an event during the week or on a weekend (usually 3-4 hours @10/hour). Summers offer more opportunity as you work registration, (can be like 4 hours a couple times a week). They assign shifts for tours based on seniority, but they are flexible with your school schedule.

pros: None, Cant think of a thing
cons: Too political, all the money is at the top...

pros: As a temp employee, pay was decent and perks were okay.
cons: Lots of back biting and office politics, incompetent managers, and self-absorbed leaders. Upper management seemed to only care about their own reputation, and would gladly let you hang yourself. Ultimately, my lack of success at this job was my own fault, but I felt that it was brought on by a lack of mentoring and direction. The climate in this department was very hostile, and it left me feeling very uneasy. I quit after 6 months because I could see the writing on the wall, but by that time, I'd already mostly checked out. Shortly before I quit, however, two senior staff members resigned (to find a less terrible place to work).

review_title: UNT ONLY if you NEED a job
job_title: Administrative Coordinator II in Denton, TX
pros: State Agency; has State regulations guiding and guarding your job security. Has some discounts and perks for being employed at campus that are useful. Town can be considered quaint and in a nice location to D/FW metroplex.
cons: State Agency; must follow strict, almost ridiculous state guidlines and regulations in all that you do.  OLD campus, old buildings, old dogs in the "big house' running things.. Most money goes to improving PhD programs, research and athletics.  Working conditions can be questionable (many buildings do not possess modern HVAC systems; rodent and insect infestation; inadequate restrooms for number of staff/student/faculty).  You WILL have to pay for your own parking and there is NO parking available unless you get there an hour+ before your work day starts... And then you will still end up walking a good clip to your office.

review_title: Favoritism abounds...get on the golden list early!
pros: Take all the politics out and this university is a good place to work.  You have a decent salary, very generous amounts of time off, the insurance is still pretty good despite some cutbacks, and depending on who you get for your boss...a decent overall working environment.
cons: University wide...it is all about favoritism.  SO...if you ever want to advance, provided you get a job where you can, then get on the golden list very early!  Many around here also like to push their weight around to get what they want and each department seems to try and out muscle the other.  LOTS of backbiting goes on around here, so be careful what you disclose to whom!  My best advice...do your job and go home!  Keep your core group of friends outside the work place!  Don't let your job become your identity!

review_title: NamUs: Social and political forces at play
job_title: Regional Administrator in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Independent investigations for missing persons. UNT HSC supplied resources to followup with law enforcement nationwide to track down and ID missing persons living or deceased
cons: Highly political. Rank comprised of vanity titles. Managers had no leadership training nor experience in field investigations. Vague unwritten policy and sub cultures conflicted with established policy and guidelines. It was a salesman type environment more than investigations into cold cases. At times budgetary constrains, dead lines, and performance markers short falls trickled down to subordinates. Examples were made upon those that had differing opinions of the direction management should take the organization. Intensity of sub groups and bad behaviors is destructive to team effort needed to succeed. Its driven more by social and politic forces than the inspiration that should be created by a talented management team.

pros: Great students and a wonderful work environment.  You teach the subjects that you love to students who want to learn about your passions.  The campus is beautiful and the kids are smart and motivated.
cons: As an Adjunct Professor, one is never sure if there will be funding for the next semester.  Consequently, I had to plan for other sources of income outside of my teaching responsibilities. Also, there are no benefits as an Adjunct Professor.

review_title: System Administration at UNT System (ITSS) – your mileage may vary
job_title: Systems Administrator II in Denton, TX
pros:
Some individual teams are true diamonds in the rough with sharp folks that want to improve things throughout the organization.

Most employees get their own office.

If you know what you're doing (technically speaking), you can influence change and you can use whatever tools you think are best.

Depends on the team, but generally speaking, the organization does not move anywhere near a break-neck speed. It's very slow and relaxed (some might say lazy).
cons:
There are way too many things that need to be improved, and the ship is so slow to turn, that the organization is more likely to attrit valuable employees than it is to adopt actual, positive change.

Clueless mid-management making dangerous decisions instead of depending on their technical folks to supply the details.

Lots of technical debt.

Pay is not competitive and options for advancement are extremely limited. Play the politics game and be prepared to wait a long time if that's something you're looking for.

review_title: Business Service Center - Project Mgr. Accounting (Systems Employee)
pros: I work at the UNT woodhill Business center -  it's a small shopping center away from campus, so the parking isn't a problem. It's a "government job".... "-nuf said"
cons:
- the pay is very, very low for what you do
- the working environment is mean and unfriendly (we were actually told in a meeting to “smile more” when we have visitors)
-  employees are disrespected (they call us “floor people”)
- employees are required to pay for parking - even though we aren't on campus (over $205 / year!!!). This is really bad since we don't make much to begin with. 
- even if I don’t have work to do, I can’t do anything else or my manager gets angry – there are hours where I just stare at a spreadsheet pretending to work – it is asinine 
- there is a predominant “this is the way we’ve always done things” attitude which filters down
- there are no “set” jobs – your duties change from day to day…which is stressful
-it's impossible to move up due to the small town/college atmosphere

review_title: Just meh compared to other Universities.
pros: Higher pay since the office is in downtown Dallas. Inexpensive parking because of supplement to parking fees for covered garage adjacent to office. Tuition benefits to family. Benefits are very good because UNT is a state institution.
cons: The location is a nightmare to commute to from just about anywhere other than Oak Cliff or downtown Dallas. The Chancellor is referred to only as "The Chancellor." That seems to be too formal for a higher education office. My floor is not friendly. There is no interfacing with other employees. In a year, I don't know most people. Training is non-existent because of this office's location. Training is offered at campus locations, but this is not a campus location. The rare time training is scheduled, it's canceled because of lack of participation.

pros: The housing department is a really fun place to get involved in and be a part of. Depending on your community director, experiences may vary (sometimes vastly), but I have throroughly enjoyed my time as a resident assistant in my specific building. They cover your housing and meal plans fees, as well.
cons: Parking not covered, and the monthly compensation is very low. Especially if you have other obligations. If you come from a lower-class family like I do, you'll probably have other financial priorities since no one is helping you with college very much. That's where compensation is difficult.

review_title: Short Staffed and Nobody in Charge
job_title: Administrative Specialist II in Denton, TX
pros: Great benefits and very flexible with schedule and time off.  Wonderful coworkers.  University President is trying to improve many aspects on campus.
cons:
Stagnant salary with no potential for growth or promotion.  Department chair is not involved or even on campus most of the time.  There are no policies or procedures and it is very chaotic with no leadership or management involved.  
The staff and faculty that do show up for work are left to fend for themselves and despite the continued tremendous growth of students and our duties, no additional staff is added.  UNT has a history of being fiscally mismanaged and my department is no exception.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Denton, TX
pros:
+ Well maintained wiki.
+ Very hands on.
+ Student workers very intelligent, motivated.
+ Student workers are innovative.
+ Many opportunities for growth, both soft skills and technical.
+ IT support staff are intelligent and know their stuff.
+ Managers are laid back and helpful.
+ University culture is laid back and doesn't try to rush you as much as other business cultures.
+ College of Arts & Sciences has a virtualized server infrastructure that is flexible and meets staff needs.
+ Culture is not so bureaucratic that you can't try out new things and be outcome oriented.
cons:
- Working part time as a student and also being a full time student is very demanding.
- You risk falling behind in school and failing classes while getting good work experience.
~ You must have an excellent way to collect and process everything you do: work, school, personal.

job_title: IT Manager I in Denton, TX
pros: UNT is a great place to work for someone who is willing to look at the holistic benefits.  While they may not offer the most competitive rates, potential is great.  They are improving in the way they handle the business side of things, as well as increasing their dependence on analytics.  This provides opportunity for people to come in, make a difference, and be somewhat rewarded for their efforts.
cons: Again, the pay is not as competitive as a corporate position.  Budgets are smaller, so you may not have the large training opportunities as other corporate.  Buildings are generally older, you'll typically be working in a slightly smaller environment.....but the campus overall is enormous and nicely landscaped.

review_title: It would be so much better if Communication was better
pros:
-Great benefit and generous amounts of time off.
-Depending on the department you work for, the salaries are great.
-Overall great atmosphere across the University.
-Fantastic facilities.
-A complete week to week and a half off at Christmas time when the University completely shuts down.
cons:
-Communication between departments is severely lacking, seems like departmental leaders like to "flex their muscles" and show other managers across campus who's boss.
-Definite favoritism and if you're liked you'll go far, if you're not liked, you won't go very far at all.
-As the University has grown, my ability to take time off has diminished.  While you're given a lot of time off, being able to use it is more and more a challenge.
-Managerial mistrust of their employees.  Severe micromanagement.

review_title: Repeatedly Hopeful Only to be Repeatedly Disappointed
pros: UNT offers good health insurance and similar benefits. There is also a certain degree of job security in that the university is growing and it is unlikely that the employer as a whole will fail.
cons: Faculty are valued far and above staff in almost every department and across campus as a whole. Funding will frequently be allotted to the faculty while the staff struggle on the same low salaries despite substantial workloads. As a whole, staff are underpaid and overworked. It is not unusual for the administration to not allow managers to replace their employees after they leave, resulting in an increasing burden on the remaining staff members.

review_title: Big picture: UNT is great; Departmentally: Some UNT departments suffer lack of leadership
pros: Depending on the department in which you work, it can be extremely rewarding to be in a position to help others advance to the next level. It is diverse and, for the most part, everyone seems to embrace the diversity. There are endless opportunities to be cuturally enriched.
cons: There are individuals who are brought into leadership positions who have no business being there. Human Resources doesn't really ever seem to want to assist employees when they are having a rough time with management. Sometimes it is difficult to work for an organization that doesn't want to focus on what the school has to offer that's exceptional. Instead, it feels as if the only push is to reach the tier 1 status.

review_title: Marketing Assistant at the UNT Union
pros: I loved my time at the UNT University Union. Having a degree-relevant position while still in school has proved totally invaluable for me. Not only that but I have a near-impossibly wonderful relationship with every single one of my co-workers. Never have I worked in such a supportive, fun, and creative environment before. I will be so sad to leave the Union, but I will have to when I graduate, as it's a student position. This job made my life and my college experience infinitely better and if I didn't have to leave to graduate, I would stay forever.
cons: Absolutely none, as far as my department was concerned. I have heard of problems in other departments at the University, but overall, I have nothing but positive things to say about my experience at the UNT University Union.

review_title: If only it paid a living wage
job_title: Administrative Specialist III in Denton, TX
pros: Great environment. Great benefits like huge discounts on tuition. They encourage their full time employees to continue their educations and celebrate their successes. They allow a lot of time off. Vacation, sick leave, holidays, and comp time  (because they do not pay overtime.) They seem to care a great deal about their employees...they call off work if their is any ice. Personally, I love the students. They satisfy my maternal instincts. I think being in this atmosphere keeps me thinking young. Lots of really nice, interesting, talented co-workers
cons: The pay is atrocious. Really really low. I have been there for 2 1/2 years and have only received one ann raise of $700.  The politics can be positively Byzantine. Better be careful not to challenge any of the long haul employees. They can find a reason to "write you up" if they want to.

review_title: Low wages, No opportunity for promotion
job_title: Part Time Book Seller in Denton, TX
pros: If you are a student at Univesity of North Texas you can get a 20% book discount after working 30 hours here.  Flexible scheduling
cons:
1) The training is poor, and given buy fellow workers who are not being paid extra for the extra work. 
2)  Expect to be hired at $7.25, and to stay close to that wage.  
3)  strange cashier log on system -Other employees can log on to your cash register
4) They expect employees not to count their till before heading out on floor. Last shift I had on cashier I went ahead and endured the glares by counting. They were a dollar over. What happens when under? 
5) Each department manager has favorites. If you end up not being trained in that department then expect fewer shifts. 
6) After the beginning rush of semester many employees only get 12 hours a week at most.  
7) Do not know how much longer this store will be open as it is.  Online sales are the stores biggest sales area. Why have they not expanded this more?

review_title: No real support from higher ups, aka President Smatresk
pros:
smaller campus

Incredible support from certain deans in academic affairs for staff, so at least there's that.
cons:
The President doesn't think that STAFF are important to academic affairs. Continuously turns our concerns from Staff Senate about not being recognized or appreciated for our major and important work into a joke. Only harps about taking care of faculty and students, especially during COVID crisis. Very odd for an institution. Especially for an institution that has staff in both student and academic affairs doing ALL the ground work when things pop off like a student being killed or discrimination on campus. WE are the ones that are in front of students. WE are important and need to feel protected as well.

No diversity in staff. Prepare to be the only POC in the room.

pros: Forced to work no more than 40hrs/ week.   Free healthcare for singles
cons:
Leadership seems to be a changing design of many chiefs with different motives and directions.  Directions are often set and then changed to suit the current person in command.  Inconsistencies in direction between Denton, HSC, Dallas and System. 

Leadership opportunities and advancement for minorities (namely African-Americans) are highly infrequest and largely nonexistant.  UNT Denton seems to operate on a "good ole boys" system whose codes only a select few can discipher.  There is disorganization and confusion in HR, Administration and  Finance.  

Overall if you seek advancement opportunity and a trivent work enviornment and you are a person of color, you'd do better to save yourself the trouble of applying, because while they may let you in the door, they'll never nurture your talent or allow you to grow.

review_title: Campus culture and surrounding city is great, immediate managers might be good, but watch out for senior leadership.
job_title: Senior Graphic Designer in Denton, TX
pros: As far as the university itself, the perks and benefits are pretty competitive even if salaries may not be. I've found that most immediate leadership is invested in their teams. Living in Denton means a great culture, same for working at UNT itself.
cons: Senior leadership may not always be willing to or able to push for growth opportunities, changes in title or responsibility.

pros:
- Excellent Benefits
- State-backed retirement program
- Relaxed work environment
- Relaxed dress code
- Relatively flexible work schedule
- Vacation/Sick/Comp time adequate
- Hands-on experience with brand new technologies
cons:
- Refuse to pay for trainings/certifications
- "Pay-band" structure, which is designed to reward employees who increase their skill sets and responsibility, is not utilized to its full potential, i.e. increased responsibility != raise. 
- Management continually reiterates the need for "transparency" but refuses to participate in providing transparency to its employees.
- Non-Competitive pay for skill sets. 
- Parking permits (required) have increased in price by 175% in the time I have worked here.

review_title: Good for working while pursuing a degree
pros: The benefits were excellent and the culture was friendly and easygoing.  When I was an employee there was a significant tuition/fees discount offered, hopefully that program is still in place.
cons: Technical decisions were often made by non-technical higher-ups, and/or by committees rather than by the employees that implemented them.  Career advancement opportunities are limited and I was led to understand that politics get worse and worse the higher you go (though I don't have direct experience with this).  It was often difficult to perform as well as I would have liked due to the bureaucracy involved.  Pay was lower than average, but acceptable -- about what you'd expect from a university.

review_title: Wonderful State Employer - Little Room for Growth - No Annual Salary Adjustment
pros:
State benefits
Ample time off
Discount to fulfill undergraduate/graduate degrees
Opportunities to find employment among various departments/divisions
Rewarding and motivating to work with students and faculty
Ample university provided training opportunities
Family oriented
cons:
Understaffed departments/divisions lead to overwhelming workloads
Little room for growth within departments/divisions
Often employees take on full workloads from employees that pass away/resign/terminated and are not augmented/compensated for the additional workload even when it becomes permanent as "other duties as assigned"
Few opportunities to reclassify a position despite overwhelming workload
Merit raises are few and far between
No annual salary adjustments including cost of living wage increases
Hiring freezes
Salary adjustment freezes
Reclassification of positions without salary adjustment

pros:
- co-workers pretty much keep to themselves…I’ve been told that’s because they are constantly watched and get in trouble if they socialize too much
-I work off campus in the business office. It’s close to a few fast food restaurants and a grocery store.
cons:
-Small minded administrators that don’t understand their own business. The excuse " this is the way we’ve always done it" is uttered constantly even though they claim to be cutting edge and implementing quality and leadership programs (it’s all hot air – nothing ever sticks). 
- Leadership is not strategic. No one thinks past 2 or 3months…because things are constantly changing. There's a definite feeling of "who cares, it's going to change anyway" going around.
- Department heads hide things from staff…we usually find information out via the grapevine…
-Compensation is way, way, way far below the average.

job_title: Hris Business Analyst in Denton, TX
pros: UNT provides good benefits including the Teacher Retirement System, and longevity pay.  The university provides tuition assistance to employees and their dependents but carefully review the program terms before participating.
cons: Executive managers are very condescending, elitist and disrespectful to subordinates while tending to create a hostile environment; frequently by design. Turnover is high.

pros: UNT has a very positive environment and you can tell that they care about their students, staff, and the larger Denton community. I have worked for the university in various capacities throughout my undergraduate career and they are always very flexible with student workers. The staffs that I have worked on have been very kind and welcoming.
cons: As a student worker, most jobs only offer minimum wage and there's a cap on how many hours student workers can have each week.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Denton, TX
pros: People are friendly, people are willing to help, there is plenty of work to keep me busy, I feel that I am gaining knowledge and experience, Denton is a nice place to live, and there are a lot of fun pubs and places to hangout with friends, coworkers, and family.
cons: Know before hand if you will be part time post doc or full time. THERE IS A HUGE DIFFERENCE IN PAY AND BENEFITS. As a part time post doc I barely make enough to live. With someone with a PhD in a hard science this is difficult to handle. I am actively searching for employment elsewhere.

review_title: New company Staff underpaid and undertrained
pros: The affiliation with UNT brought in some good consultants. Very nice facility. State of the art surveillance system. Clean. Supervisory staff was kind and tried to be helpful.
cons: Staff retention was a problem. New staff were undertrained and in this business, without proper training, the job can be quite difficult. Add to that a mediocre hourly wage and no full time positions with benefits and it was pretty much guaranteed if staff were not students studying ABA, they were not destined to remain long. Programming for clients was poor due to lack of time and busy college students providing those services. Poor management caused many problems with staff satisfaction. Without being in the field, opportunities for advancement were non-existent.

review_title: It's an okay place to work.
pros: This is a university that rising in public opinion. They are making many great strides toward excellence and success in their curriculum and yearn to be a leading research institution in the Dallas-Fort Worth region.
cons: Aside from dealing with "good old boy" hierarchies all across the campus, the pay is often less than peer institutions in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. As well, typically the work load is divided among fewer staff members than at peer institutions resulting in a heavier work load per employee.

review_title: Not bad, but expect to be underpaid
job_title: Senior Communications Specialist in Denton, TX
pros: The environment at UNT is great and most of the people there are passionate about what they do. Benefits are great (insurance is paid for the individual) and you get more time off for Christmas than any other place I've ever worked.
cons: The pay is not competitive with similar roles in other industries and merit raises don't keep up with cost of living cost increases.  Hiring is very slow, so when staff turns over you are often expected to do the work of all least two people, so the workload is often unreasonable.

review_title: Great place to start or end your career.  Not great in the middle.
pros: Friendly staff, nice working environment.  Lots of experience to be gained.
cons: Pay is about 1/2 market rate.  In most cases you could go to another company and take two demotions and still get more money.  No regular cost of living adjustments so your salary is practically stagnant.  Meaningful promotions or salary adjustments are not common.  Lots of opportunity for lateral moves at the same pay, very little room for real advancement.

pros: I'm not sure what to put here. My experience was  nothing short of horrible. Management was just awful. I've never seen such ineptitude in my life. Also, they treat you like something that comes out of the back end of a horse. I wouldn't take a job here on a bet. I'm sorry I did. There are literally no pros.
cons: You name it: they treat you like crud, they do not respect you, they lie about the job in the interview, they don't pay you anything, and so on. Most people start looking for a different job within a few months (read: very high turnover). You would think UNT would care, but they don't. They use you up and throw you out. The benefits and pay stink.

pros: When you are a student at UNT, Kerr always has an open position for you. Most of the workers there are friendly and it is easy to form a sort of community amongst your fellow workers. You get one free meal per shift. I you follow most of the regulations, it is pretty difficult to get fired.
cons: Low levels of sanitation. Harsh supervisors. Lots of pressure on people who are working around sharp, heavy, and steaming hot things. Working around food waste. When it is busy, you suffer.

job_title: Front Office Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Very flexible hours, low stress, and fun workplace. My boss was a lovely, patient woman and helped me gain the office experience that has proven invaluable.
cons: Pay was at absolute minimum, raises were routine though. The University does have some student jobs that are higher on the pay scale ($12-14) but this position was not one of them.

pros: As a part-time student worker at the Writing Lab on campus, I was able to meet fellow students and learn plenty about both the English language and tutoring first-hand. I even earned above the minimum wage! Because the Writing Lab Director is a service position for faculty, I became very close with two professors who have been great in their guidance and support of me. Needless to say, the Writing Lab is a very supportive and fun environment to work in.
cons: Because you are only allowed up to 20 hours per week, the increased wage doesn't actually translate to increased earnings.

review_title: Dead end job with favoritism for YES men
pros: You don't have a lot of violent crime, campus is nice. Some of the employees are great to work with. Vacation time is good/competitive. 50% of tuition for employees.
cons: Entitlement college kids, no room to promote, promotions go to the unqualified, Chief has no Police experience or people skills, Employees get written up for ridiculous reasons to keep them from getting yearly merit raises,  etc.

review_title: Conditions for Teaching Assistants at UNT
pros: steady work and doing something I love
cons: faculty over works teaching assistants. One faculty member frequently gave me a workload of 40  hours  a week even though I was only paid 20 hours. I wrote the syllabus for her classes, conducted mandatory one on one office hours for 48 students, wrote all homework assignments each day, developed lesson plans, graded all the assignments and final projects, and taught each class solely on my own for only part time. Faculty members would make me grade and develop lesson plans for classes I was not paid for.

review_title: Great under the radar school that doesn't care too much about its grad students
pros: There are some dynamite departments and professors on campus, lots of amenities (one of the best library systems in the U.S. and the gym is spectacular), great town, etc.
cons: But the administration of UNT really just cares about undergrad enrollment, getting them out as soon as possible. The enrollment and retention rates back me up there. There is little funding for grad students, and I've seen it promised and then never fulfilled. Beware.

job_title: IT Specialist III in Denton, TX
pros: Working on a university campus is unlike any other job you may get. The ability to go on "walking meetings" with co workers or just take five minutes and think outside in a nice environment go a long way to help productivity. You also don't take your work home.
cons: If you're a staff member and have a PhD as a boss, know going into the job that your PhD boss probably will not know how to effectively manage work well. Coming from the private sector I had overestimated how much of a difference this would actually be, but I have had zero close working relationships with my 4 bosses I've had while here.

pros:
As a math tutor, you will always have people that are looking for help.

There is opportunity to increase pay the longer you are part of the team.
 
Tutoring others really helps to understand the material at a deeper, fundamental level.
cons:
The community is quite saturated with math tutors.

The starting pay is really low. I could make 4x more as a freelance tutor.

You are on the students' time. Whenever a student needs you, they can schedule you 24 hrs ahead of time, which can ruin a lot of plans

review_title: Perfect for part time job just don’t expect to make a lot of money.
pros:
Works around class schedule 
Great coworkers
Holidays off
cons:
You are only eligible for a raise of $0.25 every 6 months and 500 hours worked in the Union. Base pay is higher than other on campus jobs but you aren’t going to make a lot of money. 
The Union also doesn’t follow the house policies that they have so if you work there and do one thing don’t be surprised if your boss tells you what you did was wrong even though it was how you were trained.

review_title: Flexible scheduling, friendly coworkers, but poor department management leaves employees frustrated.
pros: The work schedules tend to be very flexible for students, making it possible to balance work and classes. Great job skills and troubleshooting abilities learned that are useful, as well as ability to work alone or in groups.
cons: Poor department management leaves a lot to be desired. The coordinator rarely offers much assistance to stumped technicians and the manager tends to create distractions to avoid his actual duties, setting a poor example for employees.

job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: The people that I work with are wonderful and kind. They will help you if you're in need of it.
cons: Some of the student workers that they hire are more in the way than they are helping. When this was brought to the attention of the supervisor I was told to basically only worry about my work load. Even though we are supposed to work as a team and their level of work directly effects how much the rest of us have to do.

review_title: UNT is a great place to work with a strong and diverse culture
job_title: Director of Decision Support in Denton, TX
pros:
UNT maintains a collegial and collaborative environment where consensus is valued.
There is an abundance of positive energy within the UNT workforce
Many of the top-level managers have progressive attitudes toward change
cons:
UNT is not as salary competitive as the broader market
There is not as strong an alignment of strategic objectives and resources as there could be under the current threats to the sector

review_title: A great starting point as a student employee
pros: Great environment for students to work part-time, and depending on the department, get extra training and insight outside the classroom environment.
cons: Poor pay, near impossible to get an increased budget from the Student Government Assoc., as they are concerned with all the wrong info to 'qualify' a budget increase. Hard to encourage promotion of student organizations in the governing body won't support us! The University needs to relinquish some of the SGA's control over the budget, or encourage senatorial participation from groups OTHER than the fraternities and sororities. It's like a Greek country club!

pros: Wonderful colleagues and team environment in the UNT Libraries. Everyone is friendly, supportive, and eager to collaborate on new projects and research opportunities. Administrators are approachable and encouraging of new ideas. There are many opportunities for growth and professional development.
cons: There are limited job opportunities in Denton other than working in academia (UNT or TWU), unless one endures a long commute to other areas near Dallas or Fort Worth. This can be a challenge if moving to work at UNT with a spouse in another industry.

pros: You will work on a variety of projects that are interesting.
cons: Management is very bad. They go out of their way to make it uncomfortable to work in the marketing department. The major feeling is that management throws their employees under the bus. The vp is know for saying that she thinks a strong department is one of choas and crisis mode. The vp should have been fired long ago but knows all the secrets on people. All the employees in department have stress related illnesses because of the management.

review_title: Lots of job opportunities for students
pros: I had 4 different on campus jobs as a student at UNT. (Library, computer lab, TA, writing lab) I was paid on a scale from minimum wage to $15/hr. Every department was willing to work with me on scheduling for school, and it was nice to have the opportunity for time off during all school holidays.
cons: There are such a wide variety of jobs and pay scales that you'll get something completely different for each job.

pros: This university has a very open atmosphere and good teachers, it is artistic and oriented towards the creative side of life. History of community and care, students are often open minded and free spirited.
cons: Management, the Administration at UNT has some pretty horrid policies and has had serious legal issues. The management is essentially self interested and is running UNT like a "business" rather than a University. This is unhealthy and is out for profit, not education.

job_title: IT Student Worker in Dallas, TX
pros:
Flexible Student Worker Positions
Provides Real World Experience
Establishes a Good Work Expectation
Training Relative to Your Field
cons:
No Growing Room (1Yr 7Mths No Full-Time offered) 
Starting Pay (In my case, I started at max, so no raises in the year's plus hard work)
Low Salary (Understandably it is a student work position, which is only used usually for experience)
Limited Experience (You can only learn so much from one position, then it becomes repetitive)

job_title: Administrative Specialist II in Denton, TX
pros: Working with students - helping them locate resources and determine/achieve their goals. Substantial tuition break for full-time employees.
cons: Little upward growth, little training (very unorganized), department plays favorites and does not choose to challenge or use employees to their fullest potential. Barely any recognition for hard workers, and departments often turn a blind eye to problem employees. Senior management is unprofessional and allowed to say and do inappropriate things simply because of rank/position.

review_title: Awesome place to work and go to school!
job_title: Computer Lab Attendant in Denton, TX
pros:
Good Pay.
Work around school hours.
Friendly Environment.

If your lucky like me and get into a lab that is in the same building of your studies, it'll make your college life so much easier.
cons: Too many dumb rules and most of the time students are not aware of them, so they take it out on you.  It can be a very stressful environment during finals. :)

pros: (I worked at the SHWC). Having set pay days, the 15th of the month and the last day of the month. UNT depts are good about collaborating together, making correspondence and event planning easier. Typically pretty laid back atmosphere, casual attire.  Will work around class schedules.
cons: Pay is low. Hours can be long. Given down time but not allowed to leave early or work on school work.

review_title: Stay here 2 years to get experience, then go where the REAL opportunities are
job_title: Student Affairs Administrator in Denton, TX
pros:
Our division truly cares about our students
our Money Management is one of the top programs in the nation
Higher Education program offers masters students great opportunities to grow and learn the trade
cons:
The pay sucks! I know community colleges that pay more
not properly utilizing the true talent that is in our division
many programs do not truly include all employees in the division(custodial staff/maintenance)

review_title: Everyone Here understands What it Means to Be a Student
pros: The hours are extremely flexible, the staff is very accommodating; it is a fun atmosphere to work in  with people who will become some of your best friends!
cons: It is hard to work with other departments within the university at times ( if you need to for your job) as there is usually more than one campus wide event happening at the same time.

pros: People are nice, good amount of trust and comradery in the work environment.
cons: So much office BS. Don't work here is company/university culture gets you down. I am shocked daily at the amount of corporate culture BS that a UNIVERSITY has for it's employees

review_title: Good people but hard to move up
pros: Good benefits--great health insurance and retirement plan.  The tuition discount is also amazing for anyone who wants to take some classes.  The campus is nice and it's awesome to work with students.
cons: Comparatively low pay to other universities in the area.  Difficult to get promoted as a staff member, though I have no idea what it's like as faculty.

pros: Offices, departments work well around students' schedules.  Get to have fun while working in a friendly environment and earn money either to help with school, living or whatever else.  I have held several leadership positions at UNT and worked under an academic office and have always only worked with some of the most amazing and influential people in my life while studying at UNT.  Absolutely recommend working within the higher educational setting.
cons: Sometimes stressful when dealing with heavy class loads and you should DEFINITELY be well-versed in time management.  Don't burn yourself out.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Monthly stipend and full or partial tuition coverage in some circumstances. Although as a graduate student you are being directed by a professor, you still have the opportunity to tailor your research to what you are passionate about in your field.
cons: The inner workings of academia are far different than they seem. The way the assistantships are awarded often involve a great deal of favoritism. International professors prefer international students.

review_title: Your experience will greatly depend on your department
pros: Polite and friendly coworkers, benefits, and tuition discounts for employees, very friendly offices where the ultimate goal is helping the students to the best of their ability.
cons: Management in some departments are unwilling to listen to their lower staff members and will refuse to give departments more staff when desperately needed, instead opting to allow a lot of overtime to the point where people leave and have to be paid for their comp time, instead of having more staff in the first place.

pros: You have the option to obtain health insurance or not at this point. They are also moving towards paying tuition for all of the TA/RA/GSA positions.
cons: The administrative functioning of the school is not always the b st but it has gotten better. They combined some of the HR departments for UNTHSC and UNt and there wer issues for awhile. Not sure how the pay rates compare to other places.

pros: Academic environment; pay isn't bad; students are, on the whole, not a problem; supervisors were great; in-service meetings are rare
cons: As a TF, you're going to work the hours that they give you, taking your schedule into account; expect to teach two classes during spring and fall semesters, which can take a toll.

review_title: Great atmosphere, but low pay and few promotional opportunities.
pros: Really lovely people to work with and a very supportive and open management.  Upper management is very accessible and interested in the needs of their employees.
cons: Not surprisingly, being a state institution, the pay is pretty meager.  Also as a young driven professional I found that the opportunities for advancement outside of the faculty track (in more administrative roles) was pretty limited.  The organization can also be a bit bureaucratic at times.

review_title: It was a wonderful experience, one of the best jobs I've ever had.
job_title: Donor Development Representative in Denton, TX
pros: It had a Flexible management staff, with a casual environment, despite all this we still maintain a professional work ethic and got things done. In many instances we were able to meet our goals and sometimes we even exceeded them. Other than pay we were given many perks from our development team that made it worthwhile.
cons: The only problem I had was the level of compensation, although because of the other perks I didn't mind it too much.

review_title: Generally a good experience.  The professors and lecturers are happy to support you.
pros: The academic staff are all friendly and helpful.  No problems meeting up with people or getting guidance despite busy workloads.
cons: Pay rates are not substantial (but hey your working at a university).  Some of the admin staff have obviously been around too long and don't want to be there any longer.

pros: Great work environment, very flexible and great coworkers.
cons: President, VP and higher ups get huge raises and bonuses while freezing our pay for over a year. But she did note we should be very happy with our 1% cost of living adjustment!

pros: one lab's research is interesting and it is close to my family, so i chose universtity of north texsas health science center at fort worth texas as the place to work
cons: small health center and not many disciplines on the campus. the facility activity center should be open longer and more instruments should be bought for the gym.

pros: It is a great learning place. A lot of experts who are there to help us out with their knowledge and expertise
cons: International students should be give same Compensation and Benefits as they are not less than anyone else. The benefits needs to be reviewed. There should be some mandatory stuff like health insurance should not restricted as mandatory as not everyone is able to afford private insurance. Based on the fact that there are insurances that are way cheaper then UNT health Insurance.

review_title: Great company/university, supervisors very friendly and helpful
pros: The people here are great, supervisors and your coworkers will make you feel at home and will help out with anything and everything. Very flexible on schedules, allowing you to create your own schedule to fit around your classes or other jobs
cons: For those who do not have full schedules and are looking for more hours, there are limits set on weekly hours and cannot go over them, but you are allowed to hold multiple student assistant positions in different departments

review_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant at the University of North Texas
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: This position had a very flexible work schedule. My boss always gave us a reasonable amount of time to accomplish tasks. My co-workers are very reliable and pull their weight.
cons: While there aren't a lot of cons, there are a few. My boss tends to cut everyone off when they start talking if she has something on her mind. Sometimes a new person joins the team and they don't pull their weight. Sometimes I don't get paid for all of the hours I work.

review_title: Great experience for the next step...
job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Gaining invaluable experience for when I become a professor myself, flexible schedule--can work in the office or from home, low stress environment
cons: It's not uncommon for a professor to basically dump his/her entire workload on you, leaving you to wonder what exactly they are being paid to do.

review_title: A great place to build experience and skills, but low pay and little flexibility.
job_title: IT Specialist IV in Denton, TX
pros: State employees have good health benefits and retirement savings. In addition, education is typically encouraged for staff. Tuition scholarships are available and training is encouraged.
cons: The leave policies and working schedule are not flexible. Pay is much lower than in the private sector. Administrators are typically out of touch with staff concerns.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Healthy and student friendly environment that would allow you to grow as a person. Helps you learn while you teach and give back to the school.
cons: University of north Texas is a great place to work for and so far I have had only good experiences here. I highly recommend this university for international students as well as those who are seeking job opportunities here.

pros: Flexible, Location was where I spent all my time.  Was exposed to new disciplines that I would have otherwise not have seen.  I.e. worked in a lab different than my major.
cons: Giant Government Institution, Difficult to contact the correct person to fix issues.  but really it could have been much worse, given the size of the school and I am sure that operating an institution of this magnitude is no easy feat

pros:
start-up institution with a desire to respond to change quickly and efficiently
Focus more on the teaching and learning process than research
cons:
Leadership changes quickly which means that goals are less defined and change quickly.  Communication in not efficient at all levels of the institution.  
As a start up,  policies and procedures were lacking and were in the development process.

review_title: Great place to work, some politics to navigate
pros: The benefits are fantastic, the people are passionate about what they do, and the campus is a fun place to work. The student environment is one of innovation and excitement! It's very revitalizing to work with college students.
cons: There is a lot of politics to navigate in the workplace and often new programs and initiatives can take a significant amount of time to be reviewed and approved by management. The University can often be reactive instead of proactive, causing a poor image for the University.

pros: I worked at UNT as a student assistant and I loved it! I was able to work around my school schedule and not have to worry about being stressed out because of work. The university is great to work for as a student.
cons: I wish they would up the pay. I love my job but the salary is really low, considering I still do have some bills to pay. You also aren't able to work over 25 hours as a student. Which is a blessing and a curse.

pros:
This is a fantastic position, especially if you are a full-time graduate student. 
- Provides a great opportunity to see if you may enjoy teaching
- Works around your schedule, if you are a student
- Allows you to become more comfortable speaking in front of a large group
cons: Nothing really...If you are looking for a big pay check then the teaching Fellow Position might not be for you, but if you are looking for a job to help get you through graduate school, then this is a great position.

review_title: Great place for students to work
pros: Printing and distribution is full of kind people who want to see students succeed. UNT takes good care of student workers, especially through work study programs. Flexible hours (obviously they understand that school comes first), good pay, and fun office events.
cons: Some supervisors can be a little pushy or picky, but honestly it’s just one of the possible hazards of office jobs.

review_title: Kitchena and Dining career (cafetering and catering)
pros: University of North Texas give me manage skill, organization, and learning new staff in other career is not my major. However, the team work experience was incredible.
cons: Responsibilities to organize all the team the Snap food order. Keep inventory the all product we had to use in the week.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Denton, TX
pros: Opportunity to work within an education field.
cons: Opportunities for career advancement can be challenging.  Paying for parking and not having a guaranteed parking location was a constant battle.  Students, faculty, and staff all purchased the same type of parking pass.  There are not enough spaces to accommodate the parking of all; on campus anyways.

review_title: I have had an excellent learning experience at UNT.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: My professor Dr. Yan Wan is the best thing that happened to me. The department of Electrical Engineering at University Of North Texas is very skilled, innovative, energetic and helpful. I have had a great time learning and growing as a person both personally and professionally. I think it is the best career base I have formed and I am ready to step into industry now.
cons: I think the university needs to look into the way students are being payed.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Located close to DFW metroplex, good nightlife, and a very supportive staff to help you. Several professors have good contacts in the job market.
cons: Tuition assistance is lacking, and since UNT is trying to become a Tier 1 research institution there needs to be greater emphasis placed on motivating graduate students and their advisors to help make the department excel.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work!
pros: Compensation, Flexible hours, Not very busy
cons: Mismatch of position, Extra workload sometimes

pros: I worked at UNT for almost 3 years as an admissions officer. The admissions team really does go above and beyond to reach the students of UNT and make sure they are being taken care of. My team manager really cared for our personal development and was a key factor in helping me experience professional growth.
cons: Can be overwhelming with the amount of work you receive, but that's to be expected with thousands of applications being submitted every year.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Denton, TX
pros:
- Friendly staff and school morale
- Flexibility with work hours
cons:
- Graded papers/essays for 4 different courses that each had at least 100 students
- While the staff was nice, there were some issues with diversity and inclusion. As a black TA surrounded by mostly white professors, they had a fascination for my hair/extensions I wore at the time. While this may seem minor, being asked constantly to touch my hair or if it's real or not was very mentally exhausted and quite frankly rude.

job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Pretty decent for student employment pay. Flexible hours depending on the position.
cons: I was no longer needed so I was let go with no notice, the reason being that I missed an event while I was sick, even though I was told that it was fine. I did all the creative work for said event and received no credit. In Texas as a student employee you can't get unemployment benefits. I lost everything.

review_title: A Great Experience That Can Prepare You for Future Opportunities
job_title: Instructor and Student in Denton, TX
pros: You will get experience working with academics. You will learn the culture, and you will become familiar with life as a scholar if you are part of the graduate programs as an instructor and student.
cons: If you are not connected with scholars, it can be a lonely and difficult experience.

review_title: Being a TA at UNT Anthropology Department has been a very rewarding experience.
pros: As an hourly worker, I find the wage to be satisfactory even when we're only allowed to work 20 hours per month. The management and admin are extremely helpful and supportive of our roles and treat us with respect.
cons: Different departments pay its TAs different hourly wages, and they could vary from 50% to 100%. This seems to be unfair given the amount of work we all share.

pros: Room and Board payed for as part of the compensation package, better pay than most other schools. Fun people/work environment for the most part.
cons: Cliquishness and favoritism more prevalent than they should be...often favorites get away with murder while others suffer consequences for every little thing.

review_title: Teaching Assisstant for the Anthropology Department
pros: Great professors that always seemed to take an interest in their Students. Extremely well organized course structure. Hours were very comfortable and pay was great. Coworkers were majoring in the same subject, so we all had something in common
cons: Students were often quite difficult to deal with.  Many had a lack of fundamental skills necessary to complete their coursework. It was hard to help students that weren't willing to help themselves.

pros: Best Place to work as teaching assistant. Upper management is accessible. Really lovely people to work with and supportive as well. You can do your own work while you are free from the students.
cons: No hike on the career. Salary is very low. Working hour is sometime annoying.  I highly recommend this university for international students as well as those who are seeking job opportunities here.

pros: Short commute if you live in Denton.  Generous tuition discount.  Approximately two week paid winter holiday over Christmas and New Years.  Excellent pension plan.
cons: Starting salary is typically very low in comparison to the private sector.  Bureaucracy hinders change and development such as technological upgrades.

pros: good environment, good boss, well paid, the company will take care of  you and give you an environment in which you can succeed
cons: can be tough at times in the sense that you have to work even during the finals week. Other then  that there wont be a lot of other issues

review_title: Great place to work as a student!
job_title: Student Assistant of Donor Relations in Denton, TX
pros: Extremely flexible, and work with your school schedule. My supervisor was so kind, caring, understanding, helpful and encouraging. He went out of his way to help me and he's a pleasure to work for. The workload was never too much to handle while going to school full-time.
cons: absolutely no benefits and low hourly wage.

pros: There are lots of jobs available, especially if you apply before the semester begins. Great hours (you can do homework during these hours if you are not busy), schedules work around your school schedule and some jobs even offer tuition waivers for out-of-state.
cons: Mostly minimum wage or slightly above for student workers.

review_title: Stable job, competitive wages, not exciting
pros: Working for the University is a stable job - if not too stable (see below). Wages are competitive for the area, which is fairly far outside of any metropolitan areas. Work environment is very positive. Entire team is great and supportive.
cons: Hardly any upward mobility because everyone stays in their positions until retirement. No bonuses. Raises are minimal and inconsistent. Lots of tech debt (if you are involved in a tech job).

pros: My coworkers were friendly and management was generally willing to work with my schedule.
cons: Management did not discipline their student workers, generally assuming that the average student worker was lazy and that little to nothing could be done about it.

pros: Lots of paid time off, usually pretty family friendly, decent work/life balance.
cons: Lots of favoritism happens across departments on campus and the lack of communication is staggering!  The institution just joined the ranks of Texas employers who are at will so many people are literally in fear of their jobs.

pros: Good job security. The atmosphere can be positive, working in an college campus environment.
cons: The University setting is very bureaucratic. Things move at an incredibly slow pace. Change is difficult and leads to job frustration.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: better salary compared to other universities and good research projects, lot of scholarship opportunities. The faculty members are very helpful. Teaching the undergrad students in the labs is one of the greatest experiences. Living expenses in this college town is low.
cons: not well recognized for research in US. Tuition is a bit higher even if you get in-state

review_title: This has been the best place to work for a audio technician
pros: This job has been very flexible and interesting  They were very understanding  and worked aroung my class schedule.
cons: The pay could have been a little better, but it was an on campus position.

review_title: They chew you up and spit you out
pros: I can't think of any.  Seriously.... I guess it beats being jobless and homeless, but not by much.  The benefits suck and unless you're one of the fat administrators the pay sucks, too.
cons: The fish rots from the head.  And that place is ROTTEN.  I worked in the College of Business and I know it was one of the worst places on campus.  Incompetent management, cronyism, and a culture of shooting the messenger make it a nightmare.  Productive faculty get abused, and incompetence is rewarded.  Very very sad.

pros: The work is super easy, and you can watch TV on the internet or listen to music while you're working.
cons: It is so mind numbingly boring that I could barely force myself to stay awake some days. If I didn't get a full night's sleep would would seriously fall asleep mid-click sometimes.

review_title: Very flexible schedule and awesome culture!
job_title: Technical Assistant II in Denton, TX
pros: The hours were really flexible for student part time workers. I worked as an A/V tech for university events up to 29 hours a week and scheduling never was an issue
cons: Sometimes the other employees are just thrust into event setups without full training or explanations of some key things.

pros: UNT offers flexible schedules that align with your classes, so you never have to feel like you're choosing between school or work.
cons: UNT switched payroll systems twice while I was working.Once, half of my paycheck was missing because my hours were logged in the old system. I told my boss, and he got my missing money added to my next check.

pros:
nice co-workers but bad management
working for my university
cons: the business support services management is awful. I feel really sorry for the employees here. upper management backstabs them, talks bad about them, disrespects them, calls them names behind their backs (like calls them stupid or morons or dumb government workers), makes fun of them in public, its horrible

review_title: Can be a great place to work, but some managers stink!
pros: Great work environment. Very flexible. Some senior managers can "micro-manage" which stinks and some just don't trust what subordinates do.
cons: Low salary compared to industry but ok for a university. If you don't mind the lower than industry pay for any kind of skill or ability, then most of the "comfort factors" you could want are in place.

pros:
open environment which is good for international scholar to do researches
very beautiful and peaceful campus and city to live and work in
cons:
not very attractive pay but overall speaking, it is ok
not lots of room for professional advancement due to the lack of spot

pros:
-Super flexible hours which are great for studying
-Good experience to add to a resume
cons: -Staff turnover is pretty high due to students graduating, transferring, or just quitting which can become a problem because permanent staff seems to forget who you are or were when it comes to references later on.

pros: That was a job as part of my Ph.D. assistantship. I was in the College of Business. The building is new and clean. The offices and facilities are very good (two monitors and printers in the room). The classroom support team are always ready to help. The whole college is very friendly and supportive.
cons: The class size might be over 200! The pay for Ph.D. students is very average compare to the other Business Schools.

review_title: Great to be in learning environment but lots of turmoil.
job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: I enjoyed being in a learning environment and there were plenty of online tools.  Most of the people were good to work with.
cons: There was so much turmoil, people were afraid of losing their jobs and no one could get anything done.  Very antiquated for a "cutting edge" environment.

pros: I enjoy the atmosphere very much. Even though this position is not technically a Work-Study position, there is always an understanding and respect of student duties first. The environment is always supportive and very friendly. Scheduling is easy and simple.
cons: Sometimes professors can be a little too demanding (not too often, though). The pay is pretty meager with little chance of increase or advancement to higher positions.

review_title: Low pay, lots of free time
job_title: Equipment Room Clerk in Denton, TX
pros: I did homework 90% of the time that I was there.
cons: Luckily, I was living at home. IDK how you can pay rent with $8.25 an hour and a 25 hour limit.

pros: Working for UNT Housing and Residence Life was the best time of my life. It's really like having a second family. The work is hard, but worth it.
cons: Living with your coworkers can become stressful, and takes a lot of patience to get used to. Expectations are not always made clear.

review_title: Great chance to improve my coding skills
pros:
- Applied all algorithms in Data Structure, Machine Learning in Research 
- Improved coding skills 
- Got scholarship, and instate tuition
- Worked with talent team
cons: - Need to well balance between classes and researches

review_title: A great place to get your bearings
pros: All of my supervisors were very casual, and transparent about the things they were doing in the department. The pay in my department was the best on campus. Working in customer service with other students was the best experience ever.
cons: Working directly with snotty or entitled students can be a pain sometimes. During Finals week some of them get stressed out and can treat you badly

review_title: Decent College to work for, Low pay
pros: It was close to home when I was living in the dorms, lots of hours to work, met important UNT people regularly
cons: Mean bosses and strict rules make for a no fun no frills work enviorment. Pay was very low and did not make the job worth is
